questions.description: The type of magnet in which magnetic field is produced through electric current
questions.explanation: An electromagnet is a magnet in which magnetic field is produced through electric current.

questions.description: The branch of physics which deals with the magnetic effect of electric current
questions.explanation: Electromagnetism is the branch of physics dealing with magnetic effect of electric current.

questions.description: The material used as core in an electromagnet
questions.explanation: An electromagnet consists of a soft iron piece, called the core.

questions.description: The type of wire wound around the core of an electromagnet
questions.explanation: An insulated copper wire is wound in a coil around the soft iron core.

questions.description: The type of magnet that retains magnetism only when current flows through it
questions.explanation: An electromagnet is a temporary magnet which retains magnetism only when current flows.

questions.description: Two examples of permanent magnets
questions.explanation: Examples of permanent magnets are bar magnets and horse-shoe magnets.

questions.description: The type of material used to make permanent magnets
questions.explanation: Permanent magnets are usually made of hard materials.

questions.description: The type of material used to make temporary magnets
questions.explanation: Temporary magnets are usually made of soft materials.

questions.description: The two types of electromagnets based on shape
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are of two types - bar-shaped and U-shaped magnets.

questions.description: The pole formed at the end of electromagnet where current flows in clockwise direction
questions.explanation: The end where current flows clockwise acts as the south pole.

questions.description: The pole formed at the end of electromagnet where current flows in anticlockwise direction
questions.explanation: The end where current flows anticlockwise acts as the north pole.

questions.description: The part of electric bell that produces sound when struck by hammer
questions.explanation: The hammer hits the gong and sound (bell ring) is produced.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.description: The part of electric bell that pulls the armature back to original position
questions.explanation: The spring pulls the armature back to its original position.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.description: The material from which the armature in an electric bell is made
questions.explanation: The electromagnet attracts the armature made of iron.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.description: The phenomenon of producing current in a conductor due to changing magnetic field
questions.explanation: This phenomenon is called electromagnetic induction.

questions.description: The current produced by electromagnetic induction
questions.explanation: The current produced by electromagnetic induction is called induced current.

questions.description: The type of trains that use electromagnets for magnetic levitation
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in bullet trains.

questions.description: The mechanism in electric bell that causes repeated ringing
questions.explanation: The continuous making and breaking of circuit causes repeated hammer strikes.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.description: The type of board on which electric bell components are fitted
questions.explanation: Components are fitted on a flat wooden or plastic board.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.description: Heavy machinery that uses electromagnets to lift scrap iron and steel
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are used in cranes to lift heavy loads of scrap iron and steel.

questions.description: The scientist who discovered electromagnetic induction in 1831
questions.explanation: Michael Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction through his experiments in 1831.

questions.description: An instrument used to detect electric current in a circuit
questions.explanation: A galvanometer is used to detect the presence and direction of electric current in a circuit.

questions.description: The device that converts mechanical energy to electrical energy using electromagnetic induction
questions.explanation: A generator converts mechanical energy to electrical energy using electromagnetic induction.

questions.description: The device that converts electrical energy to mechanical energy
questions.explanation: An electric motor converts electrical energy to mechanical energy for rotation.

questions.description: A device that uses electromagnetic induction to change voltage levels
questions.explanation: Transformers use electromagnetic induction to step up or step down voltage.

questions.description: The property of a material to retain magnetism after the magnetizing force is removed
questions.explanation: Retentivity is the ability of a material to retain magnetism when magnetizing force stops.

questions.description: Medical imaging technology that uses powerful electromagnets
questions.explanation: MRI machines use electromagnets to create detailed images of body organs.

questions.description: The type of train that uses electromagnets for magnetic levitation
questions.explanation: Maglev trains use electromagnets to float above the track for high-speed travel.

questions.description: The motion required between magnet and conductor for electromagnetic induction
questions.explanation: Relative motion between magnet and conductor is essential for electromagnetic induction.

questions.description: The part of electric bell that completes the circuit when touching the armature
questions.explanation: The contact screw completes the circuit when it touches the armature.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.description: The type of current that flows in one direction only
questions.explanation: Direct current flows in one direction, unlike alternating current which changes direction.

questions.description: The type of current that continuously changes direction
questions.explanation: Alternating current changes direction periodically, creating changing magnetic fields.

questions.description: An experiment that tests the condition without the variable being studied
questions.explanation: A control experiment tests without the variable to establish a baseline for comparison.

questions.description: The type of test that includes a control experiment for valid comparison
questions.explanation: A fair test requires comparing results with and without the variable (control).

questions.description: The shape of electromagnet that has both poles on the same side
questions.explanation: U-shaped electromagnets have both poles on the same side for concentrated field.

questions.description: The magnetic material that can be attracted by magnets (besides iron and steel)
questions.explanation: Magnetic materials include iron, steel, nickel, and cobalt.

questions.description: The process by which electromagnets record data on magnetic tapes
questions.explanation: Electromagnets magnetize tape in patterns representing sound or data.

questions.description: The switch that connects battery to bell circuit when pressed
questions.explanation: The push button switch connects the battery to the bell circuit when pressed.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.description: The continuous closed curves that represent magnetic field around a magnet
questions.answer: Magnetic lines of force / Magnetic field lines
questions.explanation: Magnetic lines of force are continuous closed curves showing the magnetic field.

questions.description: The phenomenon where electricity and magnetism are related
questions.explanation: Electromagnetism is the branch dealing with the relationship between electricity and magnetism.
